summary: ngl a bit of my excitement died when i heard 'im gonna end it' aka the tone of the delivery of that line sounded way too bratty...
body: ngl a bit of my excitement died when i heard ‘im gonna end it’ aka the tone of the delivery of that line sounded way too bratty for a serious declaration and the line itself is kinda bad like. i have so much hope for captain marvel but as large as my hope is my gut feeling that the writers fucked it up cause why give a badass woman character depth at all. ya know. idk. i pray im wrong about this cause they fucked her up in cwii comics and God she dont need a strike 2 if we’re getting kamala khan in cm2.

summary: 'Captain Marvel' first reactions: A fun, '90s adventure with a brilliant Carol Danvers
title: 'Captain Marvel' first reactions: A fun, '90s adventure with a brilliant Carol Danvers
description:
You may believe the hype.

The much-anticipated Captain Marvel had its premiere on Tuesday night, and the first audiences to watch the film have described it as unlike any other MCU film they’ve seen before, and weirder than you’d expect.

(…)

summary: Butthurt Dudes Actually Believe 'Captain Marvel' Will Flop Because of Brie Larson
title: Butthurt Dudes Actually Believe 'Captain Marvel' Will Flop Because of Brie Larson
description:
Last week, Brie Larson made headlines when she correctly pointed out that there are way too many white dudes covering movies and made it clear that she’s not having that sh*t while promoting Captain Marvel. Predictably, the wiener-boy corners of the internet were pissed, and sure enough, our comment threads started filling up with sad rants like this one.

White male here, so you dont like white males Brie? No problem not am only going to sit out captin marvel but if you have a big roll in avengers I’ll sit that one out too. I can always stream it online for FREE. #gowokegobroke

Because I hate myself, I watched these sad, little tirades unfold, and it didn’t take long for a narrative to form because these lonely f*cknuts couldn’t form an original thought if it reached out and yanked their virginal dongs. And, folks, this narrative is a doozy:

They’re literally betting against a Marvel movie making money.

There are gambling addicts who’ve anted up their own bone marrow who look like card-counting geniuses from MIT compared to these angry dorks. But if you listen to the incelnet — which no one should ever do — they are absolutely convinced that Captain Marvel is going to be a box-office flop because Brie Larson is lighting her bra on fire and committing white genocide, or some shit. So to emphasize the fact that you should be legally declared a ward of the state if you don’t realize that Marvel is printing money right now, let’s take a look at the latest box-office predictions for Captain Marvel, which are… hmm, let’s see here… pretty f*cking great.

THR reports:

Captain Marvel is tracking to open to a marvelous $100 million-plus in North America, the biggest box-office debut since Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom stomped to $148 million last summer.

Is that projection as high as say Black Panther or Avengers: Infinity War? No. Is it almost exactly the same as a little movie called Wonder Woman? YUP.

Wonder Woman opened to $103.3 million domestically in June 2017 on its way to amassing $821.8 million globally, including $412.6 million in North America.

Long story short, you’d have to be an absolute moron to honestly believe a Marvel movie is going to bomb and especially because of a handful of triggered man-babies. So naturally, Cosmic Book News ran with that exact narrative in the most spectacularly wrong “article” that I’ve ever read in my life.

Look at this opening paragraph.

I previously wrote how Brie Larson is a huge gamble for Disney and Kevin Feige - especially following the failure of Star Wars: The Last Jedi - and now the Captain Marvel movie looks to be in big, big trouble, unfortunately.

For the record,

The Last Jedi

not only crushed at the box office, but it was one of the

highest-selling Blu-ray releases of 2018

. The Star Wars movie that truly underperformed was

Solo

, and that was because Disney tried to drop a prequel movie that nobody asked for barely five months after we just had a Star War. But somehow that’s

The Last Jedi

’s fault, according to this poster child for wearing no fewer than 12 condoms.

As a result of The Last Jedi, Disney has put the movies on hiatus for what looks to be at least another two years (no movies are coming out after Episode IX that have been announced).

To quote Luke Skywalker, “Amazing, every word of what you just said… was wrong.” But we’re not here to rehash this horseshit argument. (Maybe later.) We’re here to address this paragraph.

There is also a huge problem with Brie Larson who has been spinning Captain Marvel as a feminist movie, essentially isolating the audience, and she even recently came out against white males for some reason. I’m actually surprised and disappointed in Kevin Feige that he is allowing Larson to destroy the MCU audience, and that Disney and CEO Bob Iger haven’t learned anything from Star Wars. It’s never a good thing to split the audience or insult them. Do they not want white males to go see the movie?

Jesus Christ. It takes an extra special brand of asshole to ask, “Why are the men in charge letting this broad run her mouth?” But allow me to answer Captain Pantytwist’s question:

They know the general populace doesn’t give a f*ck about anything you’re saying because your entire worldview is insignificant, and they also know your dork-ass will be there opening day because, seriously, who are you kidding here?

See you there!

blog.description: Currently obsessed with Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D. | Other interests may crop up from time to time | Ravenclaw | Athiest | Pro-Choice | SJW | Bleeding Heart Left Coast Liberal | Love is love is love is love | You do you boo

summary: I saw Captain Marvel last night and it was everything I wanted it to be! But as an Agents of SHIELD fan, you can bet I was...
body:
Phil Coulson in Captain Marvel

I saw Captain Marvel last night and it was everything I wanted it to be! But as an Agents of SHIELD fan, you can bet I was paying close attention to everything having to do with Phil Coulson whenever he was on screen (which wasn’t a lot). I’m going to put my thoughts so far under the cut. There’s nothing plot specific here that will give away any big reveals in the movie, but I’m also tagging it with a spoiler tag anyway, just to be safe.

  • First of all, be aware that Coulson is only a minor side character in this. It’s kind of misleading that they have him in the trailer and gave him a whole character poster. He has maybe 10 minutes of screen time, if that. Even the cat (who turned out to be my favorite character) is on screen more.
  • Coulson hasn’t been an agent for very long when the movie takes place (it’s set in the ‘90s). Fury calls him “the new guy” and doesn’t know him that well yet, but there is a moment that explains why Fury trusts and respects him from the beginning, and why Coulson will later become his chosen successor.
  • The computerized de-aging technique is done really well, almost distractingly so. One drawback is that it doesn’t allow for a lot of expression on Clark’s part, although when you think back to how Phil was when we first met him in the MCU, he wasn’t super expressive anyway, so it fits the character I guess.
  • Coulson doesn’t meet any blue-skinned Kree face to face in the movie, but it’s reasonable to speculate that Fury will fill in the details about them, and the Skrulls as well, at some point.
  • There isn’t anything in the movie that specifically rules out the Skrull theory in S6. The rules for the MCU Skrulls (as established in the movie) are: 
  1. They have to see someone to copy them. 
  2. They can match a person’s DNA, fingerprints, and most biological data, so there’s no way to physically tell them apart. 
  3. It takes a combination of practice and talent to be really good at it. 
  4. Probably most importantly, Skrulls can retain short-term memories, but not long-term ones. So if a Skrull saw Coulson in a non-SHIELD context, the organization might not be in the double’s memory. 
  5. On the other hand, they are supposed to be skilled at infiltration, so it’s hard to believe they wouldn’t have at least heard of SHIELD if they’ve spent any time on Earth. 
  • Personally, I don’t buy the theory, but I do find it interesting. Since we’ve had plenty of Kree on the show now, I wouldn’t be surprised if the Skrulls appeared at some point. Just because the writers like to keep us miserable guessing.

That’s all for now! If you have any more questions that I can answer (publicly or privately), send an ask.

  • First of all, be aware that Coulson is only a minor side character in this. It’s kind of misleading that they have him in the trailer and gave him a whole character poster. He has maybe 10 minutes of screen time, if that. Even the cat (who turned out to be my favorite character) is on screen more.
  • Coulson hasn’t been an agent for very long when the movie takes place (it’s set in the ‘90s). Fury calls him “the new guy” and doesn’t know him that well yet, but there is a moment that explains why Fury trusts and respects him from the beginning, and why Coulson will later become his chosen successor.
  • The computerized de-aging technique is done really well, almost distractingly so. One drawback is that it doesn’t allow for a lot of expression on Clark’s part, although when you think back to how Phil was when we first met him in the MCU, he wasn’t super expressive anyway, so it fits the character I guess.
  • Coulson doesn’t meet any blue-skinned Kree face to face in the movie, but it’s reasonable to speculate that Fury will fill in the details about them, and the Skrulls as well, at some point.
  • There isn’t anything in the movie that specifically rules out the Skrull theory in S6. The rules for the MCU Skrulls (as established in the movie) are: 
  1. They have to see someone to copy them. 
  2. They can match a person’s DNA, fingerprints, and most biological data, so there’s no way to physically tell them apart. 
  3. It takes a combination of practice and talent to be really good at it. 
  4. Probably most importantly, Skrulls can retain short-term memories, but not long-term ones. So if a Skrull saw Coulson in a non-SHIELD context, the organization might not be in the double’s memory. 
  5. On the other hand, they are supposed to be skilled at infiltration, so it’s hard to believe they wouldn’t have at least heard of SHIELD if they’ve spent any time on Earth. 
  • Personally, I don’t buy the theory, but I do find it interesting. Since we’ve had plenty of Kree on the show now, I wouldn’t be surprised if the Skrulls appeared at some point. Just because the writers like to keep us miserable guessing.

That’s all for now! If you have any more questions that I can answer (publicly or privately), send an ask.
trail.content:
Phil Coulson in Captain Marvel

I saw Captain Marvel last night and it was everything I wanted it to be! But as an Agents of SHIELD fan, you can bet I was paying close attention to everything having to do with Phil Coulson whenever he was on screen (which wasn’t a lot). I’m going to put my thoughts so far under the cut. There’s nothing plot specific here that will give away any big reveals in the movie, but I’m also tagging it with a spoiler tag anyway, just to be safe.

  • First of all, be aware that Coulson is only a minor side character in this. It’s kind of misleading that they have him in the trailer and gave him a whole character poster. He has maybe 10 minutes of screen time, if that. Even the cat (who turned out to be my favorite character) is on screen more.
  • Coulson hasn’t been an agent for very long when the movie takes place (it’s set in the ‘90s). Fury calls him “the new guy” and doesn’t know him that well yet, but there is a moment that explains why Fury trusts and respects him from the beginning, and why Coulson will later become his chosen successor.
  • The computerized de-aging technique is done really well, almost distractingly so. One drawback is that it doesn’t allow for a lot of expression on Clark’s part, although when you think back to how Phil was when we first met him in the MCU, he wasn’t super expressive anyway, so it fits the character I guess.
  • Coulson doesn’t meet any blue-skinned Kree face to face in the movie, but it’s reasonable to speculate that Fury will fill in the details about them, and the Skrulls as well, at some point.
  • There isn’t anything in the movie that specifically rules out the Skrull theory in S6. The rules for the MCU Skrulls (as established in the movie) are: 
  1. They have to see someone to copy them. 
  2. They can match a person’s DNA, fingerprints, and most biological data, so there’s no way to physically tell them apart. 
  3. It takes a combination of practice and talent to be really good at it. 
  4. Probably most importantly, Skrulls can retain short-term memories, but not long-term ones. So if a Skrull saw Coulson in a non-SHIELD context, the organization might not be in the double’s memory. 
  5. On the other hand, they are supposed to be skilled at infiltration, so it’s hard to believe they wouldn’t have at least heard of SHIELD if they’ve spent any time on Earth. 
  • Personally, I don’t buy the theory, but I do find it interesting. Since we’ve had plenty of Kree on the show now, I wouldn’t be surprised if the Skrulls appeared at some point. Just because the writers like to keep us miserable guessing.

That’s all for now! If you have any more questions that I can answer (publicly or privately), send an ask.

summary: Here's the thing: the reason I'm not posting any Captain Marvel stuff is because I wanna be surprised, so I only saw the...
body:
Here’s the thing: the reason I’m not posting any Captain Marvel stuff is because I wanna be surprised, so I only saw the official trailers and this new video that came out today. Apparently I have self control when it comes to her, but not The Avengers.

Also I’m tired of guys saying “But Captain Marvel was a guy.”

Here is a picture I took of her costume at ccxp last December.

summary: Hope van Dyne, Groot and Nick Fury for the Marvel Asks ^^
question: Hope van Dyne, Groot and Nick Fury for the Marvel Asks ^^
answer:
Thanks for asking! ^-^

Hope Van Dyne: expectations for ‘Captain Marvel’?

ONLY THE BEST! *^*

Seriously, the trailer got me really hyped up! Not just because she is the first female Marvel hero to get a standalone movie, or because she is a super hot badass, but also because Carol is one of those characters I’ve seen in smaller roles in the cartoons repeatedly but never really got satisfying origin story to watch or much focus on her! So I’m excited for more about her, because in the cartoons she is already such a great character.

And so far the tailers made it look exciting and cool and I love her already! *^*

Groot: I am Groot?

I am Phoe! :D

Nick Fury: what actor would you like to see join the mcu and for what role?

That… That is such a fucking good question oh my gods. Wow.

Okay so stupidly obvious one is Dominic Sherwood as Johnny Storm in the Fantastic Four reboot that’ll tie into the MCU. Young, cocky, gorgeous blonde who can control fire. It’s a perfect fit. *grins broadly*

(Emilie de Ravin as Susan Storm, Santiago Cabrera as Reed Richards and Dwayne Johnson as The Thing - come ooon, the Rock as the Thing would be perfect! Also Christian Kane as Doctor Doom. Because I can.)

Marvel Asks

summary: Please can Captain Marvel not just #make everything better. Mostly, because I want the characters we know, and have been living...
body: Please can Captain Marvel not just #make everything better. Mostly, because I want the characters we know, and have been living with for 10+ years to defeat  Thanos and rescue their friends & half the universe; not simply [insert new amazing character who just can sort everything]. It’s so… deux ex.

summary: Early Captain Marvel Reviews Are Positively Glowing
title: Early Captain Marvel Reviews Are Positively Glowing
excerpt: While some men want to try and tank the film on Rotten Tomatoes, the actual reviews from Captain Marvel seem positively radiant.
